Barrett and Benzoin
Star.

The. Varsity basket-ball team
suffered defeat Friday night, 23 to
13, at the hands of Rutgers, but at
any rate it gave every spectator a
run for his money, and made the
Rutgers team fight its hardest to
At half time Rutgers had just
forged into the lead, 13 to 12. A
IL! inute before Hopkins had
brought cheers to the throats of
all by staging a rally of three
quick successive field goals. But
the lead, 12 to 11, was too slender
to maintain. Benzoin. Rutgers'
'star forward, came through with
two goals from the foul mark,
which ended Hopkins' period of
leadership. Throughout the game
the Varsity contributed fouls when
Rutgers was most needing them,
and Benzoin leaped on the opportunities like a cat and made the
most of them.
The first half was bitterly contested from whistle to whistle—
first Rutgers then Hopkins in the
lead. Rutgers seemed to have
more skill, but the Varsity was in
the fighting with a power that
could not be denied. Although
Benzoin was easily the Rutgers
star, the Hopkins n-ten'fought as a
team, and no particular star can
be mentioned.
But the second half was clearly
Rutgers'. Benzoin seemed a whilwind that Hopkins could not stop.
When the Black and Blue covered
the sacred region near their goal,
he dodged and side-stepped after
• the most approved big-league manner, and often forced an opening
for a score. Rutgers scored 10
Points to 11 for Hopkins in this
half.
The idea that Rutgers was play.inir around with Hopkins is childish. Had they wished to save
themselves for the clash with
Navy, it is not probable that they
would have allowed Benzoin to
take the roughing that he got. In
fact„ the whole team was corn:
pletely fagged at game time.
The Freshmen had an easy time
With Severn. Thirty to 8 is a very
nice score, hut the Freshies excelled the River boys even more
than the score indicates. The
Whole Freshman team put up a
good game, but Short and Griffin
played most of the game for
Severn.

Bill Wood (captain), star. of
the Black and Blue football squad,
has decided to accept an appointment to the West.Point Military
Academy. Provided he passes the
mental and physical entrance
tests, Bill will don the gray next
July. He thus gives up his study
of medicine and -decides on an
Army career after spending three
years in pre-medical work.
The tactics which Army is now
said to be employing to develop a
championship football team have
aroused a,great amount of discussion and adverse criticism all over
the country. The Military Academy, it would seem, has for the
past year been inaugurating a recruiting drive for the leading football stars of other colleges. The
most important additions to the
Army squad last season were
French and Storck, of Rutgers,
Mullikin, of Columbia.
and
Among those reported to have
been approached more recently
.by the recruiter are McMillan,
center; Flowers, Georgia Tech;
Boynton, Williams, Urban and
Fitzpatrick, Boston College; Tarbish, W. & J; Lourie, graduating
from Princeton this year, and, of
particular interest to Hopkins'
supporters, Bill Wood, recently
elected to captain of this University's 1921 team.
When interviewed recently upon
the subject of Army's tactics
Coach Van Orman, Hopkins athletic director, said that he could
not be quoted too strongly as being
entirely opposed to West Point's
system of weaning football stars
away from the smaller colleges.
In his opinion Army, on account
of its system of appointments,
which carry with them all living
expenses and. a certain amount of
spending money, is able to "get
away" with methods which are
bound to hurt amateur athletics
and against which practically
every college in the country is
fighting to bring about a higher
standard of sportsmanship.
Army's only excuse for its recruiting athletes is that athletes
make better officers and are better
fitted to train enlisted men in
their various lines. If this is the
case, then it is a question why the
West Pointers have not approached college men who have
starred in other branches of
sport. Of added, interest is the
fact that the Army people have

By shattering three records,
equaling another and performing
well all around, the United States
Naval Academy swimmers were
able to swamp the Hopkins representatives in a dual meet last Saturday at Annapolis by a 51 to 11
score.
The meet opened with the 160yard relay, in which the future
admirals finished with the splendid time of 1 minute 17% seconds,
a second and three-fifths under the
former mark. In the plunge, the
two Navy men had little difficulty
in defeating Hambleton, who,
nevertheless, showed much improvement over his work earlier in
the season. Emory of the Academy, equaled the record of 19 seconds in the 40-yard dash, Gallagher, his team-mate, and Rowland,
Hopkins' captain, following in
order.
The 40-yard back-stroke
event furnished the thrill of the
contest, McIntosh of Navy nosing
out.Reins and Hall of Hopkins by
but few feet. Sinclair, star of the
meet for Navy, succeeded in cutting 71/5 seconds from the Intercollegiate record for the 220-yard
swim, negotiating the distance in
2 minutes 23% seconds. He was
followed by Fish and Coady of
Navy and Hopkins, respectively.

SOPHS PLAN TO GIVE PROM

The chief business of the Sophomore class, called by 0. D. Collins
after the Assembly on Thursday,
was the formulation of plans for
a large class prom which will be
held some time during March. The
committee of seven men appointed
was the same that arranged the
banquet last year which is long to
be remembered by the class and
some of the present Juniors. It
is composed of D. K. Vanneman,
J. B.'Powell, J. E. Howard, J. T.
Thompson, J. R. Sherwood and A.
Aaronson. It is considered best
to have the dance previous to the
traditional banquet, which will be
held later in the year.

smaller colleges, making no advances to members of such institutions as Harvard, Yale, Princeton, Cornell, Pittsburgh and Syracuse, which have the political
power to put West Point in a
class by itself and cut it from the
schedules of practically every college in the country.

Honor System to Apply to Quizzes.
Two Men Expelled This Year.
Changes Made in Council
Membership.

The Student Council, desiring as
it does the full co-operation of the
'student body in general in the
cently made public some of the recently made public some of its results of its efforts. In all of its
decisions the Council has the
backing and confidence of the
Dean and of the Committee on
Student Affairs; it wishes to enjoy in like manner the support of
those whom it represents — the
undergraduates.
President Stansbury holds that
one of the chief aims of the Student Council should be the elimination from the University of
those whose moral standards render them manifestly unfit to associate with the other students.
In accordance with this general
purpose, the Council has held that
the honor system applies to all
the work of the various classes,
and not to examinations alone.
The quizz paper should be just as
much a "one-man" affair" as the
formal half-yearly examinations.
During the early part of the
present year two men were,at different times tried for cheating on
quizzes. Both plead guilty, but,
strangely enough, each man made
the statement that he took the
work of another "unconsciously,"
without any intention of being dishonest. Since, however, they were
both proved to have violated the
honor, system, the Council was
forced to ask for their immediate
withdrawal.
One of the two
ignored this first request, but a
second demand proved effective.
A third student, summoned to
answer for a minor offense, left
the University without appearing,
although the charge against him
would in no ease have merited expulsion.
It is, of course, recognized by
the Council that a great deal of

MAJOR ARTHUR DE BLES
ADDRESSES STUDENT
ASSEMBLY
Receives Enthusiastic Applause Of
Student-body. "The Intellectual
Aspects Of The Allied Victory" His Topic.

The Student Assembly on
Thursday was addressed by Major
Arthur de Iles of the British
Army, who spoke on the subject
"The Intellectual Aspects of the
Allied Victory." Major de Bios
has had a very interesting career;
in Paris at the outbreak of the
war in August, 1914, he organized
a regiment which was three-fifths
American, similar to Roosevelt's
rough-riders at San Juan. He
spent three and one-half years in
the trenches, became British administrator of the city of Cologne
and was made a chevalier in the
Legion of Honor on account of
his distinguished service.
Major De Bles reviewed thoroughly and in a most interesting
manner the causes which led to the
outbreak of war and then discussed the various movements of
armies and the most important
battles from the beginning of the
German advance until the signing
of the armistice. Much information not generally known was
given, which was interspersed with
witty remarks and humor, so characteristic of the typical Englishman.
How brains won the war was
The
the gist of the lecture.
strategical and tactical movements
of armies were explained in detail
on maps made by the speaker. He
said that the French are the greatest strategists and cited Joffre,
who used tactics at the battle of
Namur similar to those of Napoleon at Jena hundreds of years
ago, as a typical example.
The manner in which the German defeated himself by attempting to wage a successful war on
two fronts simultaneously was discussed. The transfer of troops
from the western to the eastern
theater. of war weakened the lines
of defense and thus brought about
an earlier victory.
The Boche had an inordinate
delight in boasting about his
achievements, and for this very
reason the allied forces were able
to gain valuable information as to
the number of men on the front,
the reserves and losses. This was
one mistake the Germans made.
Another was a political mistake—
when the treaty of Litovsk was
drawn up the purpose of the German army on the western front
was not concealed. The Hindenburg line could not have been
broken by an allied attack but
by the German attack the famous
line made up of 77 divisions was
swept aside.
General Ludendorff had hoped
to be able to bring the war to
a successful completion before
American troops arrived in

Over 40 men have been reporting to Captain Mullikin and Dr.
Lloyd for the daily track practices. This is the largest squad
Hopkins has had in years and,
with a few more field men in training, prospects would be very
bright.
Three practices were held last
week at the Armory and three at
Although the actual
the field.
running has been very hard, an
unusual amount of attention has
been paid to the exercises every
man is required to take. These
are calculated to give the men the
sfapina to face the unusually hard
schedule which confronts them.

"Guild Socialism" To Be Subject Of
Lecture.

"Guild Socialism" will be the
subject of a lecture to be given by
Dr. Harry W. Laidler, secretary
of the Intercollegiate Socialist Society, prominent economist, author
and lecturer, on January 24 in the
C. E. Building under the auspices
of the Social Science Club. The
meeting is open to all interested.
France and thought he was doing
very well until the attack at
Chateau-Thierry when, much to
his surprise, he found 650,000
Americans fighting with the British and French and that there
were many more in reserve. The
advance through the Argonne
finally led to the presenting of the
armistice terms which Germany
accepted and hostilities ended.
Major De Bles gave an example
of German psychology. During
maneuvers in France before the
outbreak of the war a German
military attache, with offices in
Paris, was injured; upon his recovery he was given the medal of
the Legion of Honor. The war
broke out shortly after and he
went back to Germany. When the
commissioners from the German
army appeared before General
Foci to receive the terms of armistice this man came in wearing the
medal which had been awarded
him. General Foch said "I authorize you to remove that medal,"
and he did.
In closing he added that above
all the intellectual lessons of the
war must not be forgotten, that
in life as well as in war a battle
won is one which yau know you
can win, and all that is needed is
a strong will and determination.
This lecture was by far the most
interesting given so far, as was
evidenced by the applause of the
student-body and their demand
that the speaker continue although
the period was long up. The meeting did not close until 30 minutes
after the usual time.

TRYOUTS FOR TOCQUEVILLE
CONTEST FEBRUARY 11
"France As a Colonial Empire" To
Be Subject For 1921. Hopkins,
Harvard and Princeton Only
Eastern Colleges To Have
Privilege Of Awarding
Coubertin Medals.

The Tocqueville medal for this
year has been received through the
French Government from the
donor, the Baron Pierre de Coubertin. The subject for the 1921
contest will be "France as a
Colonial Power." Speakers will
choose subtopics, such as "The
French and Their Dependent Peoples," "French Colonials on the
War," "French Policy in Algiers."
Preliminary trials to select the
contestants will be held February
11 at 12.20 o'clock in Room
112. At these trials five-minute
speeches will be adequate. All
undergraduates are eligible to
compete.
The 1920 medal was won by
John H. Lewin of the Senior class
and was formally presented as a
part of the class day ceremonies.
Few honors open to a Johns Hopkins student are equal to this in
lasting significance. Among eastern colleges Johns Hopkins shares
only with Harvard and Princeton
the honor of awarding one of the
Coubertin medals to its undergraduates each year. The opportunity to win a place in the final
contest, which will probably take
place early in April, should not
be lightly valued. For the four
years preceding 1920 the winners
of the medal were the following:
Warren M. Driver, 1919; William
S. Hoffman, 1918; Joseph L.
Krieger, 1917, and Reuben Oppenheimer, 1916.
Zionist Society Gives Dance.

The Zionist Society held a very
successful dance at the Synagogue
House of the Madison Avenue
Temple last Sunday night. Over
50 couples attended and among
these were a few members of the
Alumni. Due to the success of
this dance others will be held in
the future at which all Hopkins
men will be welcome.
The study circles, that is, the
"History of Zionism," on Monday
at 12.30 o'clock, and the Hebrew
Conversation Circle on Tuesday,
at 12.30 o'clock, held weekly in
Room 113, Gilman Hall, are making much progress. Prof. Henry
Walter of Dropsie College is expected to address the society some
afternoon in January. A cordial
invitation is extended to all those
interested to attend the society's
circles and socials.

ELECTRICAL CLUB ORGANIZED

SENIOR BUDGET TO BE $32

Last Friday at 4.15 o'clock an
organization meeting of the Johns
Hopkins Electrical Club was held
in Room 104, M. E. Building.

This Sum Will Include All Class Expenses—Payment Desired by
April 1.

Viessman, who opened the meeting, was elected temporary chairman; Salter, secretary, and Fuld,
treasurer, to hold office until the
second Friday in February, when
a regular election of officers will
be held and a constitution adopted.
The committee now working on the
constitution consists of Ball
(chairman), Mahle and Weikle.
This club is not to be confused
With the previous ones of the same
name which have existed at the
University. It is founded on a
new idea. Though not a branch
of the American Institute of Electrical Engineers, only members of
the A. I. E. E. shall have membership in the club. In this way
everyone will be acquainted with
the work of the institute, a worldwide organization, a membership
in which keeps one in touch with
all proceedings of interest to electrical engineers.
Meetings will be held on the second and last Friday of each
month, speakers being selected
from the faculty and the studentbody.
There will be no dues, a small
initiation fee being the only
charge.
The purpose of the club shall
be:
1. To promote a friendly and
fraternal feeling among the undergraduate students in electrical engineering.
2. To promote interest in the
study of electricity and to aid in
the maintenance of high standards
at the University.
3. To promote the welfare of the
electrical profession in the community.

According to the budget presented by T. F. Hubbard at the
Senior class meeting in Room 110,
M. E. Building, last Thursday it
will cost each Senior the sum of
$32 to graduate. This is made up
of five items calculated by the
budget committee to be the maximum assessment for each activity—Hullabaloo,$20; banquet, $5;
Senior prom, $5; class day exercises, $1; incidentals and dues, $1.
The $20 for the Hullabaloo Will
include two copies of the year
book and all the expense of individual pictures and snapshots. It
was found that no action could be
taken by the dean or college authorities on any man who failed
to pay the sum before graduating
so that the only punishment will
be exclusion from the Hullabaloo
and class activities. In order to
facilitate the collection a motion
was passed to have all money collected by April 1. The pin committee reported on three types of
pins one the old type gotten in the
Freshman year and two new ones,
both more elaborate. The class
decided on retaining the old design which can be obtained at the
A. H. Fetting Manufacturing Jewelry Company, 213 North Liberty
street, for $2.75.
Graham Heiner, editor of the
Hullabaloo, then requested that all
Seniors get in their individual activity list within the next week.
He also asked for personal snhpshots and reported that one of the
staff photographers would be on
hand every Thursday afternoon at
the Barn to take personal pictures
of anyone who is unable to procure one in any other way.

dent would realize what it means
to the faculty and the various activities at Hopkins, he surely
would not hesitate in seeing Mr.
Myers at once and securing a postoffice box.
The boxes in use at the present
time could be replaced for better
ones, preferably those having keys.
Much time, trouble and possible
loss of important letters or papers
would be lessened to a great degree if the old boxes were removed.
The boxes having combination
locks are not altogether ideal, but
are quite an improvement over
the glass-front boxes; combinations are often very easily manip
ulated, which is one disadvantage
not to be overlooked.
If each and every student would
rent a box, more money would be
available for improvements badly
needed in the postoffice; by holding off a student is denying not
only himself but the remainder of
the student-body the advantages
to be gained from an efficient postoffice system.
Trusting that this letter will
reach the eyes of some of those
who have not sdcured postoffice
boxes, and that they will realize
just how much they are retarding
the installation of new and better
boxes and a more efficient system,
I am

IS THERE TO BE A NEW CLUB
AT HOPKINS ?

BLUE SERGE SUITS
FOR YOUNG MEN, $33.50

There has appeared on one of
the bulletin boards of the University the following notice of the
organization of a new club. This
makes another new group to add
to our list of small clubs. The
signatures of men who wish to
join were affixed to the notice but
there seems to be some which the
NEWS-LETTER is unable to find on
the list at the Registrar's office. It
might be thought advisable for one
of the clerks to look at such
notices for men who have been
negligent in signing the card in
the office. The notice follows:
IMPORTANT NOTICE.
The Southpaw Club will hold
its reorganization meeting for the
current year some time during the
coming week. The Southpaw Club
was a power in social circles at
Homewood during the past years
and the help of all eligible men
iS needed to put it back on the map
where it belongs. Not only those
men who scoop up their soup with
their port flippers, but also those
lads who think left-handed or
shimmy from the larboard are
asked to join. All eligibles please
sign below. Come on boys, help
boost the organization that has
produced such men as Lefty Looie,
George Chaney, Boob McNutt,
Rube Marquard and Billy the
Rid!
G. U. Bit, E. Z., Ura Phool, Ima
Knott (Boob's cousin), O. B.
Happy, 0. G. Whiz, U. Die and
I. Berry (undertakers), Jas. M.
ITpp, Al K. Hall.

THE JOHNS HOPKINS NEWS-LETTER, JANUARY 18, 1921

THE TURKISH
CIGARETTE

BOXING TEAM DISBANDS
The boxing team has definitely
decided to disband for the year.
After sending John Marcuse to
the meeting of the Intercollegiate
Association in New York lack of
financial support has compelled
the promoters of the sport at Hopkins to give up.
The Varsity Club and the Athletic Association had decided to
support the sport, but other activities and precarious financial
conditions have compelled them to
make this support purely moral.
There is a possibility of a reorganization for producing an informal team such as the wrestling
experiment. It is probable that
"Doc" Rhodes, the popular trainer,
will take a number of the sluggers
under his wing and teach them a
few•things for their private satisfaction. Rhodes is a former pug
and knows a lot about the game.
(Continued from page 4, col. 4)

Ghent, Louvain and Brussels. I
am very much obliged to the
Romance Department for having
advised my coming to this University, as the French here is so
very much better than that at
Brussels or Ghent. Professors
Wilmotte and Doutrepont of the
Romance Languages Department
have been very pleasant, and the
Rector of the University, Monsieur
Eugene Hubert, has shown me
every courtesy possible.
The courses are given admirably, but what is so different from
our universities is the fact that it
makes no difference whether the
professor arrives 10 minutes or
half an hour behind time. When
the professor enters the room
there is much respect shown him,
for all the students stand up.
There was a "seance solennelle"
to mark the opening of the academic year, and in the course of
his announcements the'Rector welcomed officially "the three American Fellows who would be at
Liege." I happened to be the only
one present.
There are two series of lectures
to be given here this winter under
the auspices, respectively, of the
League for the Extension of the
Culture of French and "les
Amities Francaises." The Comedie
Francaise is to give a play every
other Wednesday, beginning November 10, and continuing through
the winter, and there is also a club
of students which I am told it
is well worth while to join. I
have therefore a great many remarkable opportunities for talking and hearing excellent French
outside of class hours.
I am, moreover, very pleasantly
placed in the family of the Protestant Pastor of Liege. There are
four sons and a daughter, and all
exceedingly helpful in correcting
my mistakes of pronunciation.
Very appreciative of what you
have done for me and 'apologizing
again for not having written
sooner, I am,
-Very sincerely yours,
Louis H. NAYLOR, A.B., 1917.

BASKETEERS TO MEET VIRGINIA ON FRIDAY
Contest To Be Staged At Richmond.
Next Game To Be Played At Home
Will Be With Haverford On
February 4.

The Johns Hoilkins Basketball
Team will journey this Friday to
Richmond to meet the University
of Virginia. It is thought that
the chances for a victory for the
Black and Blue are exceedingly
favorable.
The next basketball game at
home will be against Haverford
and will be staged Friday, February 4 at the Armory. It will
be preceded by a game between the
Freshmen and Tome School. Both
these games should be closely contested, as Haverford will be out
for revenge for her defeat in football, and Tome has one of the best
prep school teams in the State.
On the eleventh the Varsity will
clash with Washington and Lee.
As this game will inaugurate a
very close athletic relationship
with the generals -the team is
straining every effort to make time
occasion auspicious. The Freshmen will tackle Donaldson before
this game. As the first-year men
have been going very well, they
ought to have but little trouble
with the boys from Ilchester. On
both these nights a feature will be
made of the dancing. "Bob" Iula's
Orchestra will be in the limelight
and if the crowds seem to warrant
it more space will be reserved for
(lancing.

Bill Wood (captain), star. of
the Black and Blue football squad,
has decided to accept an appointment to the West.Point Military
Academy. Provided he passes the
mental and physical entrance
tests, Bill will don the gray next
July. He thus gives up his study
of medicine and -decides on an
Army career after spending three
years in pre-medical work.
The tactics which Army is now
said to be employing to develop a
championship football team have
aroused a,great amount of discussion and adverse criticism all over
the country. The Military Academy, it would seem, has for the
past year been inaugurating a recruiting drive for the leading football stars of other colleges. The
most important additions to the
Army squad last season were
French and Storck, of Rutgers,
Mullikin, of Columbia.
and
Among those reported to have

Fitzpatrick, Boston College; Tarbish, W. & J; Lourie, graduating
from Princeton this year, and, of
particular interest to Hopkins'
supporters, Bill Wood, recently
elected to captain of this University's 1921 team.
When interviewed recently upon
the subject of Army's tactics
Coach Van Orman, Hopkins athletic director, said that he could
not be quoted too strongly as being
entirely opposed to West Point's
system of weaning football stars
away from the smaller colleges.
In his opinion Army, on account
of its system of appointments,
which carry with them all living
expenses and. a certain amount of
spending money, is able to "get
away" with methods which are
bound to hurt amateur athletics
and against which practically
every college in the country is
fighting to bring about a higher
standard of sportsmanship.

case, then it is a question why the
West Pointers have not approached college men who have
starred in other branches of
sport. Of added, interest is the

Honor System to Apply to Quizzes.
Two Men Expelled This Year.
Changes Made in Council
Membership.

The Student Council, desiring as
it does the full co-operation of the
'student body in general in the
cently made public some of the recently made public some of its results of its efforts. In all of its
decisions the Council has the
backing and confidence of the
Dean and of the Committee on
Student Affairs; it wishes to enjoy in like manner the support of
those whom it represents — the
undergraduates.
President Stansbury holds that
one of the chief aims of the Student Council should be the elimination from the University of
those whose moral standards render them manifestly unfit to associate with the other students.
In accordance with this general
purpose, the Council has held that
the honor system applies to all
the work of the various classes,
and not to examinations alone.
The quizz paper should be just as
much a "one-man" affair" as the
formal half-yearly examinations.
During the early part of the
present year two men were,at different times tried for cheating on
quizzes. Both plead guilty, but,
strangely enough, each man made
the statement that he took the
work of another "unconsciously,"
without any intention of being dishonest. Since, however, they were
both proved to have violated the
honor, system, the Council was
forced to ask for their immediate
withdrawal.
One of the two
ignored this first request, but a
second demand proved effective.
A third student, summoned to
answer for a minor offense, left
the University without appearing,
although the charge against him
would in no ease have merited expulsion.

Receives Enthusiastic Applause Of

Aspects Of The Allied Victory" His Topic.

The Student Assembly on
Thursday was addressed by Major
Arthur de Iles of the British
Army, who spoke on the subject
"The Intellectual Aspects of the
Allied Victory." Major de Bios
has had a very interesting career;
in Paris at the outbreak of the
war in August, 1914, he organized
a regiment which was three-fifths
American, similar to Roosevelt's
rough-riders at San Juan. He
spent three and one-half years in
the trenches, became British administrator of the city of Cologne
and was made a chevalier in the
Legion of Honor on account of
his distinguished service.
Major De Bles reviewed thoroughly and in a most interesting
manner the causes which led to the
outbreak of war and then discussed the various movements of
armies and the most important
battles from the beginning of the
German advance until the signing
of the armistice. Much information not generally known was
given, which was interspersed with
witty remarks and humor, so characteristic of the typical Englishman.
How brains won the war was
The
the gist of the lecture.
strategical and tactical movements
of armies were explained in detail
on maps made by the speaker. He
said that the French are the greatest strategists and cited Joffre,
who used tactics at the battle of
Namur similar to those of Napoleon at Jena hundreds of years
ago, as a typical example.
The manner in which the German defeated himself by attempting to wage a successful war on
two fronts simultaneously was discussed. The transfer of troops
from the western to the eastern
theater. of war weakened the lines
of defense and thus brought about
an earlier victory.
The Boche had an inordinate
delight in boasting about his
achievements, and for this very
reason the allied forces were able
to gain valuable information as to
the number of men on the front,
the reserves and losses. This was
one mistake the Germans made.
Another was a political mistake—
when the treaty of Litovsk was
drawn up the purpose of the German army on the western front
was not concealed. The Hindenburg line could not have been
broken by an allied attack but
by the German attack the famous
line made up of 77 divisions was
swept aside.
General Ludendorff had hoped
to be able to bring the war to
a successful completion before

"Guild Socialism" To Be Subject Of
Lecture.

"Guild Socialism" will be the
subject of a lecture to be given by
Dr. Harry W. Laidler, secretary
of the Intercollegiate Socialist Society, prominent economist, author
and lecturer, on January 24 in the
C. E. Building under the auspices
of the Social Science Club. The
meeting is open to all interested.

very well until the attack at

Americans fighting with the British and French and that there
were many more in reserve. The
advance through the Argonne
finally led to the presenting of the
armistice terms which Germany
accepted and hostilities ended.
Major De Bles gave an example
of German psychology. During
maneuvers in France before the
outbreak of the war a German
military attache, with offices in
Paris, was injured; upon his recovery he was given the medal of
the Legion of Honor. The war
broke out shortly after and he
went back to Germany. When the
commissioners from the German
army appeared before General
Foci to receive the terms of armistice this man came in wearing the

him. General Foch said "I authorize you to remove that medal,"
and he did.
In closing he added that above
all the intellectual lessons of the
war must not be forgotten, that
in life as well as in war a battle
won is one which yau know you
can win, and all that is needed is

This lecture was by far the most

that the speaker continue although
the period was long up. The meeting did not close until 30 minutes
after the usual time.

TRYOUTS FOR TOCQUEVILLE
CONTEST FEBRUARY 11
"France As a Colonial Empire" To
Be Subject For 1921. Hopkins,
Harvard and Princeton Only
Eastern Colleges To Have
Privilege Of Awarding
Coubertin Medals.

The Tocqueville medal for this
year has been received through the
French Government from the
donor, the Baron Pierre de Coubertin. The subject for the 1921
contest will be "France as a
Colonial Power." Speakers will
choose subtopics, such as "The
French and Their Dependent Peoples," "French Colonials on the
War," "French Policy in Algiers."
Preliminary trials to select the
contestants will be held February
11 at 12.20 o'clock in Room
112. At these trials five-minute
speeches will be adequate. All
undergraduates are eligible to
compete.
The 1920 medal was won by
John H. Lewin of the Senior class
and was formally presented as a
part of the class day ceremonies.
Few honors open to a Johns Hopkins student are equal to this in
lasting significance. Among eastern colleges Johns Hopkins shares
only with Harvard and Princeton
the honor of awarding one of the
Coubertin medals to its undergraduates each year. The opportunity to win a place in the final
contest, which will probably take
place early in April, should not
be lightly valued. For the four
years preceding 1920 the winners
of the medal were the following:
Warren M. Driver, 1919; William
S. Hoffman, 1918; Joseph L.
Krieger, 1917, and Reuben Oppenheimer, 1916.
Zionist Society Gives Dance.

The Zionist Society held a very
successful dance at the Synagogue
House of the Madison Avenue
Temple last Sunday night. Over
50 couples attended and among
these were a few members of the
Alumni. Due to the success of
this dance others will be held in
the future at which all Hopkins
men will be welcome.
The study circles, that is, the
"History of Zionism," on Monday
at 12.30 o'clock, and the Hebrew
Conversation Circle on Tuesday,
at 12.30 o'clock, held weekly in
Room 113, Gilman Hall, are making much progress. Prof. Henry
Walter of Dropsie College is expected to address the society some
afternoon in January. A cordial
invitation is extended to all those
interested to attend the society's
circles and socials.

ELECTRICAL CLUB ORGANIZED

SENIOR BUDGET TO BE $32

Last Friday at 4.15 o'clock an
organization meeting of the Johns
Hopkins Electrical Club was held
in Room 104, M. E. Building.

This Sum Will Include All Class Expenses—Payment Desired by
April 1.

Viessman, who opened the meeting, was elected temporary chairman; Salter, secretary, and Fuld,
treasurer, to hold office until the
second Friday in February, when
a regular election of officers will
be held and a constitution adopted.
The committee now working on the
constitution consists of Ball
(chairman), Mahle and Weikle.
This club is not to be confused
With the previous ones of the same
name which have existed at the
University. It is founded on a
new idea. Though not a branch
of the American Institute of Electrical Engineers, only members of
the A. I. E. E. shall have membership in the club. In this way
everyone will be acquainted with
the work of the institute, a worldwide organization, a membership
in which keeps one in touch with
all proceedings of interest to electrical engineers.
Meetings will be held on the second and last Friday of each
month, speakers being selected
from the faculty and the studentbody.
There will be no dues, a small
initiation fee being the only
charge.
The purpose of the club shall
be:
1. To promote a friendly and
fraternal feeling among the undergraduate students in electrical engineering.
2. To promote interest in the
study of electricity and to aid in
the maintenance of high standards
at the University.
3. To promote the welfare of the
electrical profession in the community.

According to the budget presented by T. F. Hubbard at the
Senior class meeting in Room 110,
M. E. Building, last Thursday it
will cost each Senior the sum of
$32 to graduate. This is made up
of five items calculated by the
budget committee to be the maximum assessment for each activity—Hullabaloo,$20; banquet, $5;
Senior prom, $5; class day exercises, $1; incidentals and dues, $1.
The $20 for the Hullabaloo Will
include two copies of the year
book and all the expense of individual pictures and snapshots. It
was found that no action could be
taken by the dean or college authorities on any man who failed
to pay the sum before graduating
so that the only punishment will
be exclusion from the Hullabaloo
and class activities. In order to
facilitate the collection a motion
was passed to have all money collected by April 1. The pin committee reported on three types of
pins one the old type gotten in the
Freshman year and two new ones,
both more elaborate. The class
decided on retaining the old design which can be obtained at the
A. H. Fetting Manufacturing Jewelry Company, 213 North Liberty
street, for $2.75.
Graham Heiner, editor of the
Hullabaloo, then requested that all
Seniors get in their individual activity list within the next week.
He also asked for personal snhpshots and reported that one of the
staff photographers would be on
hand every Thursday afternoon at
the Barn to take personal pictures
of anyone who is unable to procure one in any other way.

dent would realize what it means
to the faculty and the various activities at Hopkins, he surely
would not hesitate in seeing Mr.
Myers at once and securing a postoffice box.
The boxes in use at the present
time could be replaced for better
ones, preferably those having keys.
Much time, trouble and possible
loss of important letters or papers
would be lessened to a great degree if the old boxes were removed.
The boxes having combination
locks are not altogether ideal, but
are quite an improvement over
the glass-front boxes; combinations are often very easily manip
ulated, which is one disadvantage
not to be overlooked.
If each and every student would
rent a box, more money would be
available for improvements badly
needed in the postoffice; by holding off a student is denying not
only himself but the remainder of
the student-body the advantages
to be gained from an efficient postoffice system.
Trusting that this letter will
reach the eyes of some of those
who have not sdcured postoffice
boxes, and that they will realize
just how much they are retarding
the installation of new and better
boxes and a more efficient system,
I am

THE JOHNS HOPKINS NEWS-LETTER, JANUARY 18, 1921
IS THERE TO BE A NEW CLUB
AT HOPKINS ?

BLUE SERGE SUITS
FOR YOUNG MEN, $33.50

There has appeared on one of
the bulletin boards of the University the following notice of the
organization of a new club. This
makes another new group to add
to our list of small clubs. The
signatures of men who wish to
join were affixed to the notice but
there seems to be some which the
NEWS-LETTER is unable to find on
the list at the Registrar's office. It
might be thought advisable for one
of the clerks to look at such
notices for men who have been
negligent in signing the card in
the office. The notice follows:
IMPORTANT NOTICE.
The Southpaw Club will hold
its reorganization meeting for the
current year some time during the
coming week. The Southpaw Club
was a power in social circles at
Homewood during the past years
and the help of all eligible men
iS needed to put it back on the map
where it belongs. Not only those
men who scoop up their soup with
their port flippers, but also those
lads who think left-handed or
shimmy from the larboard are
asked to join. All eligibles please
sign below. Come on boys, help
boost the organization that has
produced such men as Lefty Looie,
George Chaney, Boob McNutt,
Rube Marquard and Billy the
Rid!
G. U. Bit, E. Z., Ura Phool, Ima
Knott (Boob's cousin), O. B.
Happy, 0. G. Whiz, U. Die and
I. Berry (undertakers), Jas. M.
ITpp, Al K. Hall.

THE JOHNS HOPKINS NEWS-LETTER, JANUARY 18, 1921

THE TURKISH
CIGARETTE

BOXING TEAM DISBANDS
The boxing team has definitely
decided to disband for the year.
After sending John Marcuse to
the meeting of the Intercollegiate
Association in New York lack of
financial support has compelled
the promoters of the sport at Hopkins to give up.
The Varsity Club and the Athletic Association had decided to
support the sport, but other activities and precarious financial
conditions have compelled them to
make this support purely moral.
There is a possibility of a reorganization for producing an informal team such as the wrestling
experiment. It is probable that
"Doc" Rhodes, the popular trainer,
will take a number of the sluggers
under his wing and teach them a
few•things for their private satisfaction. Rhodes is a former pug
and knows a lot about the game.
(Continued from page 4, col. 4)

Ghent, Louvain and Brussels. I
am very much obliged to the
Romance Department for having
advised my coming to this University, as the French here is so
very much better than that at
Brussels or Ghent. Professors
Wilmotte and Doutrepont of the
Romance Languages Department
have been very pleasant, and the
Rector of the University, Monsieur
Eugene Hubert, has shown me
every courtesy possible.
The courses are given admirably, but what is so different from
our universities is the fact that it
makes no difference whether the
professor arrives 10 minutes or
half an hour behind time. When
the professor enters the room
there is much respect shown him,
for all the students stand up.
There was a "seance solennelle"
to mark the opening of the academic year, and in the course of
his announcements the'Rector welcomed officially "the three American Fellows who would be at
Liege." I happened to be the only
one present.
There are two series of lectures
to be given here this winter under
the auspices, respectively, of the
League for the Extension of the
Culture of French and "les
Amities Francaises." The Comedie
Francaise is to give a play every
other Wednesday, beginning November 10, and continuing through
the winter, and there is also a club
of students which I am told it
is well worth while to join. I
have therefore a great many remarkable opportunities for talking and hearing excellent French
outside of class hours.
I am, moreover, very pleasantly
placed in the family of the Protestant Pastor of Liege. There are
four sons and a daughter, and all
exceedingly helpful in correcting
my mistakes of pronunciation.
Very appreciative of what you
have done for me and 'apologizing
again for not having written
sooner, I am,
-Very sincerely yours,
Louis H. NAYLOR, A.B., 1917.

Post No. 1, bugbear of all
guard mounters, was in charge of
a rookie, learning his apprenticeship at Fort Crook, Neb. Just
after midnight the blackness of
the night was broken by his cry:
"Corp'ril of the guard; Number
1.; drunken prisoner."
A long pause and then:
"Never mind the corp'ril;
drunken prisoner's gone away."
Crool, Crool!

sounds of mirth and jollification.
"Say, buddy," said Post No. 2,
just over and green to the job,
"what does P. C. stand for, anyway?"
"Oh, that?" answered Post No.
1, an old-timer. "That means
Pinochle Club."

BASKETEERS TO MEET VIRGINIA ON FRIDAY
Contest To Be Staged At Richmond.
Next Game To Be Played At Home
Will Be With Haverford On
February 4.

The Johns Hoilkins Basketball
Team will journey this Friday to
Richmond to meet the University
of Virginia. It is thought that
the chances for a victory for the
Black and Blue are exceedingly
favorable.
The next basketball game at
home will be against Haverford
and will be staged Friday, February 4 at the Armory. It will
be preceded by a game between the
Freshmen and Tome School. Both
these games should be closely contested, as Haverford will be out
for revenge for her defeat in football, and Tome has one of the best
prep school teams in the State.
On the eleventh the Varsity will
clash with Washington and Lee.
As this game will inaugurate a
very close athletic relationship
with the generals -the team is
straining every effort to make time
occasion auspicious. The Freshmen will tackle Donaldson before
this game. As the first-year men
have been going very well, they
ought to have but little trouble
with the boys from Ilchester. On
both these nights a feature will be
made of the dancing. "Bob" Iula's
Orchestra will be in the limelight
and if the crowds seem to warrant
it more space will be reserved for
(lancing.
